title: Friday, 13th September 2019

11:15 am
JP11:15am

Numis Views: Woodford Patient Capital’s share price already reflects a large degree of scepticism about the valuation of the unquoted assets given that it closed last night at 45.3p, representing 38% discount to the NAV of 72.85p on 11 September. The shares are down 5% this morning, leaving the fund on a 38% discount to the NAV adjusted for the write-down.

JP11:15am

We are not surprised to see further write-downs in the portfolio and believe these may continue. It is disappointing that disclosure around these write-downs and the portfolio exposure has been limited during these uncertain times for the fund. As a result, we believe sentiment towards WPCT is likely to remain weak. There has been widespread concern about the value of holdings such as Industrial Heat and we believe that many investors may already have written-off the full value of these investments when pricing the stock.

JP11:15am

The Board is currently assessing its options regarding the future management of the fund and we believe that the appointment of a new manager could be a catalyst for a turnaround in sentiment. However, we remain wary of the stock until there is greater clarity over the timing of any management/strategic developments and greater portfolio disclosure.

JP11:25am

You don't say.

BE11:25am

Who can summarise? Peel Hunt? That'll do.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Adj PBT fell by 4.5% to £102.5m, in line with our forecast and consensus, even though this figure includes a £2.7m increase in profits in disposal. Without disposal profits, adj PBT fell by 7% to £96.9m. The result was mostly driven by 6.8% LFL sales and a 56bps reduction in EBIT margins due to limited drinks pricing growth. With early 2020E LFL sales up 5.9%, we are holding our forecasts and Hold recommendation. The 20x P/E rating is full in our view, but the potential and sensitivity to price increases is growing, but there are no signs of this taking place.

BE11:25am

LFL sales growth was 6.8% in 2019, split: 5.8% drink; 8.3% food; 10.3% slot/fruit machines; and 3.9% accommodation. Despite this LFL growth, freehold reversions and more tail-end closures, we estimate average profit per pub grew by only 0.5%. The company did not pass higher costs on to customers, sacrificing margins to drive higher sales. H1/H2. PBT fell by 23% in H1, with LFL sales rising by 6.3% and EBIT margins falling by 180bps despite the benefit of £56m of freehold reversions reducing the rent roll. In H2, LFL sales rose by 7%, resulting in EBIT margins rising by 60bps. As drinks prices did not increase, we believe the margin improvement was due to higher food prices and slightly easier cost pressures. Drinks pricing. According to CGA, Wetherspoon’s average beer price is £2.94 (unchanged), whereas the industry average increased by 3.3% to £3.92 over the year to June 2019. As a result, Wetherspoon’s average pricing discount to the industry has increased to 25%, up from 19% in 2016. Expansion. Only five pubs/hotels opened and nine were sold or closed. The emphasis remains on maintenance capex, tail-end disposals and freehold reversions, benefiting LFL sales and margins. The company intends to open 10-15 pubs in 2020E. IFRS 16 will apply to 2020E’s results. The company estimates that it will affect 2020E as follows: EBITDA should increase by c£58m and operating profit by c£8m. The interest charge should increase by c£22m and profit before tax should decrease by c£14m. On the balance sheet, a net lease liability of c£617m and total assets of c£618m should be recognised. There will be no impact on cash flows except in relation to tax payments. Net debt rose by just £10m in 2019 even though £77m was spent on freehold reversions and £5m was spent on share buy backs.

Big dog Denzel Tim Martin looks like he's slowly morphing into a Yes and/or Rush tribute band bassist.
BE11:25am

The reason we do not have a negative recommendation is that there is capacity for the company to raise drink prices, and the profit sensitivity to this is large, as we saw in 2017, when earnings rose by 43%. Higher pricing is the catalyst in our view, but it is unlikely to occur at this stage in the political cycle, particularly whilst the Chairman is focused on highlighting the cost/pricing benefits of Brexit to the company’s customers.

Soundbuy Post Armageddon only Spoons and Greggs will be left
11:26 am
JP11:26am

(@Big dog Denzel -- he's no Geddy Lee)

BE11:26am

(@Big dog Denzel: "a homeless Thundercat," I saw on Twitter a while back.)

JP11:26am

Here's Shore Capital Markets:

11:26 am
JP11:26am

Adjusting for c£6m of profit on disposals, underlying PBT for the year to July 2019 came in at £97m, which was some £5m below our forecast and £7m behind the £104m reported last year. The shortfall was both at the operating level and slightly higher interest; operating profit was flat year-on-year. Although, JDW continues to deliver on the top-line, with LFL sales ahead by a staggering 6.8%, albeit the contribution from net new units is modest (+0.6%), conversion to the bottom line remains difficult with operating margins down 70bps in the year to 7.3%. For balance, the operating margin was negatively impacted by higher repair & maintenance in the year and was modestly up H2 over H1, although the improvement was below our expectations, especially given the strength in LFL sales

JP11:27am

As expected, net debt increased by £10m to c£737m reflecting ongoing share buybacks and a high number of freehold reversions – a debt/EBITDA ratio of 3.4x. We would expect this investment strategy to continue, although new build development remains modest with 10-15 new openings expected in the current year. The group has also provided estimates for the impact of IFRS-16, which lowers 2019A PBT by £22m, increases EBITDA by £58m and adds some £617m of lease liabilities to the balance sheet – a lease adjusted debt/EBITDA multiple of 5x.

JP11:27am

Current trading remains strong, with LFL sales ahead by 5.9% in the six weeks to 8th September and the group expecting “a reasonable outcome [pre IFRS-16] for the current financial year”, which we read as flat to modestly ahead. With consensus (Bloomberg compiled) currently at c£103m we see some modest downside risk to forecasts.

JDW trades on over 11x 2019A EV/EBITDA, sharply above peers. With an EBITDA per pub of £2.7m, sharply above it’s pre-financial crises highs we retain our SELL stance on the stock.

PBateman Love how cable nudging 1.25 is shock and awe these days :D

While the company has delivered very strong LfL sales growth for an extended period, profits are static, we think any sales reversion towards more normal levels by industry and historical levels could put pressure on the premium valuation, though industry consolidation could provide valuation support.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Want Morgan Stanley to say "on reflection we think you should buy stocks"?

BE11:34am

#1 In the very short term Momentum looks tactically oversold... After the sharp momentum rotation the RSI of European Momentum has fallen below 30 for the first time this year, which has been a very effective tactical buy signal for momentum in recent years.

#2 … but Momentum remains expensive ... The correlation between Momentum and bond yields is close to its most negative ever levels. Short-term tactical signals give a positive message for Momentum, yet the highly depressed level of bond yields suggest the Momentum correction may have further room to run.

#3 … and bond markets suggest further room for Momentum to fall. The recent drawdown in Momentum’s performance makes the factor look less stretched than it did a few weeks ago, yet it still trades slightly above its 12 month average, and valuations of the factor remain in the 80th percentile of the historical range.

#4 Could improving money supply growth signal a trough in EU PMIs? Our economists remain cautious on the growth backdrop, but there are a few indicators that might hint towards a more optimistic view. In Europe, real M1 growth has historically led the manufacturing PMI and suggests an imminent improvement. Credit growth is also at a decade high.

#5 Valuations of Value vs Growth more extreme in Europe than the US. Valuations of Value vs Growth in Europe matched their TMT-bubble lows, yet in the US the valuations of Value vs Growth are still some way off their lows. In Europe Value vs Growth is heavily Underweight defensive sectors, but the opposite is true in the US.

#6 Banks still trade close to a record low relative to 'fair value'. Before their recent bounce, Banks traded at a historical wide relative to their fixed income based ‘fair value’ and still trade very low versus history. The sector’s gap to fair value has historically correlated well with subsequent 6M returns

BE11:35am

#REF! @VV75 thought they reverse that
11:36 am
BE11:36am

And Lapthorne at SocGen, who's always value for money.

BE11:36am

What happened: This week we saw some of the most extreme factor moves ever, with Value stocks bouncing back strongly and Quality stocks suffering. Both on Monday and Tuesday, we experienced factor performances unseen in more than ten years, across all major regions. What is astonishing is that at the same time global equity markets barely moved. So, this was not the typical Value rally of a bull market, but a strong reversal of the Quality vs Value trade.

What was the context: We have been arguing, for some time now, that Value stocks are extremely cheap and Quality stocks or bond proxies were expensive. We had a polarised equity market created by collapsing bond yields, which has been a feature of the market since QE came along but went to extreme levels over the summer. What created this problem was fear of an impending slowdown and a search for perceived safety. Any asset with volatility and drawdown was to be avoided. Value being both volatile and cyclical and having underperformed for almost three years was shunned. Bond yields plummeted further this summer, which has led Value to underperform further and, more importantly, to a rally in all things “bond-like”. A strong reversal was always a risk.

What was the trigger: Over the past week bond yields have broken their downtrend and bounced back strongly. The force of the moves highlights how polarised the markets are. Essentially, the Quality versus Value trade gave back months of gains in two days. Many investors are stressing out as most of the things they own have lost money quite quickly. Conversely the one thing they don't own Value stocks and cyclical risk more generally, has rallied.

What are the lessons: Bond risk in equity markets should not be overlooked. Our primary argument for Value was not dependent on accelerating GDP growth or an economic regime change, but largely about the need to diversify interest rate risk, a point we made a year ago when rates were rising. The same applies today. There is too much bond price momentum priced into asset prices and to hedge this risk you need to buy cyclical upside, that might be bank stocks, autos, the Nikkei 225 or Value, which by definition is a portfolio of the world's problems.

What is next: Value stocks are still attractively valued, but they will most likely require positive economic news flow to extend their rally. Despite some relief from macro fears and trade talks, the economic environment has not changed. Rates and credit spread moves following the upcoming central bank meetings will be key to watch. Value has already given back some of its gains in Europe following the ECB meeting today. Irrespective, investors need to diversify their bond and bond proxy risk. Too many investors are poorly exposed to positive news. Value stocks, a portfolio of doom-laden stories as we have seen in recent days, provide such a hedge.

2s10s @BE: cheers for strat grey

11:39 am
BE11:40am

(In dollars)

JP11:40am

Oh go on...

BE11:40am

Recent developments: Parliament has ruled out a no deal Brexit at least for now by forcing the government to ask for an extension if it is unable to agree on a deal with the EU before the 19th of October. We agree with our economists that the chances of a no deal Brexit is now much lower, while an early election looks very likely (see CS House View).
It could be argued that a Conservative Majority (not relying on the DUP) would enable Boris Johnson to impose a sea border between Mainland UK and Northern Ireland, avoiding the need for an Irish backstop. A Minority government (whether Conservative or Opposition) would most likely lead to a second referendum. In the EU election, 40% of the electorate voted for Remain parties versus 34% for no deal/hard Brexit parties and thus we think a referendum is unlikely to end in a no deal/hard Brexit. Recent polls show that a Labour majority government looks very unlikely, though we believe the Lib Dems/SNP are more likely to have a ‘confidence and supply’ deal than a formal coalition with Labour which might allow some of Labour’s taxation policies to be implemented. We continue to believe the chance of a deal on the Irish backstop have been underestimated.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

■ UK growth – cause for optimism: Inventory levels have normalized after an unprecedented large destocking in Q2, fiscal easing of 1.5%+ of GDP under both a Conservative or a Labour led government, rising real wage growth and European economic momentum troughing should underpin an acceleration in growth to 1.2% for 2019.
■ Sterling – modest upside: Given the improved political backdrop, one of the currency's biggest headwinds is fading. At the same time Sterling is abnormally cheap on PPP (having depreciated peak to trough by 22% nearly in line with its normal bear market of 25%), investors are unusually short, and FDI has already collapsed.
■ FTSE 100 – to overweight in USD terms: Our macro model (based on Sterling, oil, GEM and lead indicators) show a 15% upside for the index and our aggregate valuation measures are trading close at a 20 year low. Moreover, outflows are extreme and risk appetite is the most depressed of all major regions. One of the biggest challenges for the UK market is just 23% of revenues for the FTSE 100 are domestic, with 41% of market cap reporting either in dollars or euros. Given our more optimistic view on Sterling, we would therefore be overweight the FTSE 100 in single currency rather than local terms.

BE11:40am

Risks remain:

BE11:40am

................. aye, a bit.

11:40 am
JP11:40am

Teeth smile

BE11:40am

The withdrawal bill is the easy part and trade agreements are the hard part, with PM Johnson seemingly favouring the harder Brexit, Canada+ plan.

BE11:41am

What to buy? We would buy UK international earners in dollar terms that are cheap versus their peer group e.g. Johnson Matthey, Elementis, Rentokil, Relx, BAT. Of the domestic areas we would highlight airlines (Easyjet), and utilities (SSE), which have become unusually cheap versus their European peers, abnormally lagged the rally in index linked bonds with the nationalization risk sharply diminished. Other Outperform-rated domestic stocks include BT and United Utilities. We are benchmark UK retailing and banks (the most sensitive sector to gilts & sterling), and underweight UK REITs and homebuilders.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

That's Andrew Garthwaite and team.

BE11:41am

Anything to add to strategy corner, JP?

2s10s @JP: you teased some Autos grey.
JP11:42am

The Frankfurt Motor Show stuff from MS analyst Harald Hendrikse is good. If we're talking big picture research:

11:42 am
JP11:43am

Focus on EVs, whereis the Golf or Passat? BEVs have properly broken through. Where four years ago the BEV concepts were in small side rooms at the show, they are centre stage now. All of the OEMs showing cars in Frankfurthad BEV models or concepts at the core of their range. At VW Brand, the ID.3and other BEV concepts took over 80% of the stand. It was tough to even find the Golf or Passat. At Porsche, the Taycan took centre stage. At Skoda, the Citigo e iV with 165mile range at €20k was at the core. And SEAT even had two BEVs - the El born and the Seat Cupra Tavascan. Mercedes showed its Vision EQS concept,
whilst BMW had its BMW I hydrogen Next - showing justhow BMW has different priorities from its competitors. Renault showed its new Captur, with PHEV option available,and talked aboutnew BEV versions of the Twingo and a small crossover. Honda had its new Honda e, which will be available at£26k. Hyundai had a retro E45 electric concept.Land Rover's defender will be available with four ICE engines. A number of other major OEMs didn’t even show cars at the show - including all the FCA brands, Peugeot brands, GM Chevy and Cadillac, Rolls-Royce, Aston Martin,and even Dacia - as well as all Japanese brands bar Honda.

2s10s BEV = Battery EV
JP11:44am

Microsoft instead ofFCA, Google or not: One of the missing OEMs at Frankfurt was FCA, with its glamorous linked Maserati, Alfa Romeo and Ferrari brands. In place of all of these cars were now supplier stands, dominated by of all auto suppliers, Microsoft with a very large stand. This may best represent where the auto sector stands today. The value of the software in the car is rising sharply and quickly and is forcing difficult decisions on the OEMs. Can they develop this core skill? OEMS face having to move from integratingup to 100 ECUs in a large premium model, with different software languages from up to 200 suppliers to a single integrated automotive control system using between one and three
centralised computers. OEMS have the option to use Aptiv's expertise in
electrical architecture, or other suppliers, they can use Google's developing Android Auto system,and or Chinese alternatives, or they can build their own operating system. Whilst FCA, GM,and Renault Nissan have all agreed to integrate at least some Google software (with a loss of control over data), VW, of course, is building its own system vw.os.

BE11:44am

There was a certain amount of optimism about Frankfurt in the leadup, on the idea that all the bad news was already out there and the OEMs were looping the trough.

11:44 am
JP11:44am

One more para:

BE11:44am

("looping the trough" is a horrible phrase for which I apologise.)

2s10s phev = photo-voltaic ev
GBKrona @BE - big part of evolving strategy this week is that Trump realises he must back off trade wars with China, Iran etc - else his chances of re-election next year limited?
JP11:45am

No Frankfurt warnings isgood enough: Whilst we recognise the many downside economic risks,auto demand risks,and structural earnings risks, we think a lot of risks are priced in to the autos sector,even after the recent rally - especially now thatnumbers for 2H 2019 have been downgraded.Further, we believe that as global auto comps get easier from Q32019,and monthly data turns more positive,as it is doing in China,autos could continue to rally to the end of 2019. or even into FY20 - normally a period of stronger cyclical performance. We continue to believe that the QE decision confirmed by the ECB for November 2019 could extend such a sentiment rally for European autos. Any credible effort from the OEMs themselves to restructure, reduce costs, or better yet - reduce
spending to improve FCF – could drive a more sustained re-rating of the sector. We maintain Overweight ratings on the qualitytire names (Continental, Michelin, Pirelli), but we are also Overweight Renault, BMW and Daimler. See our latest slide deck here for our latest sector view and detailed work on CO2 and BEV earnings impacts. We remain Underweight on Peugeotand Volvo.

BE12:00pm

Here's Alphavalue.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

We believe the probability of this deal succeeding is close to zero. However, this should feed speculation regarding other giant market venues (ICE or CME, for instance) bidding on the UK market venue. It will support LSEG’s share price in the short term. In any case, we remain positive on the stock (even on a standalone basis).

BE12:01pm

I'll point out again that ICE and CME have had decades to bid for LSE. The idea that they'll be flustered into making an approach now seems a bit basic.

BE12:02pm

The M&A theme regarding LSEG has been part of our investment case on the company and has long supported the share price. It has, besides, enjoyed a sharp positive momentum since the announcement of the acquisition of Refinitiv.
Hence, this offer is not that surprising and there is a good probability the US market venues, ICE and CME, could soon bid on the company as well.
However, the HKSE bid is by far the least attractive. The offer might have been interesting for the LSEG’s shareholders (and the board and management might have supported the deal) if it was fully-cash financed (40% versus price before the LSEG/Ref deal was announced). But only 1/4tr of the acquisition would be financed in cash with the rest paid in HKSE shares.
This financing proposal with the condition to drop the Refinitiv deal would leave far too many uncertainties for LSEG’s shareholders. We still believe that the Refinitiv deal has the potential to create more value for shareholders (even above the price proposed by HKSE).
Then, there are the politics. HK is at the moment a sensitive issue (social unrest) and this is even more true as the HK government is HKSE’s main shareholder.
And, given LSEG’s current activities in clearing in the US, the US authorities would certainly look deeply into the deal (with a high probability of blocking it…no need to remind how complicated the economic relations are between the US and China).
The UK authorities might not like the deal either. Once again, a merger or
acquisition between market venues is likely to raise political issues (we remember the failed DB/LSE deal in 2016).

VV75 pound being low is in their favour, it could help swing their thought.
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

And some Redburn, from yesterday.

BE12:03pm

LSE’s proposed acquisition of Refinitiv redefines its investment case. Execution risk is undeniably high, but embedded with Refinitiv are three world class assets – Tradeweb, its FX platforms, and the Refinitiv/Elektron data platform. The combined entity offers strong gearing to two of the most powerful structural trends in capital markets – electronification of trading and demand for data. The headline multiple of LSE looks elevated, but will fall rapidly as enormous EPS accretion materialises. HKEX’s approach underscores the value embedded within LSE Group, however we see significant uncertainties attached to this bid. In our view, substantially greater long-term value lies in the Refinitiv deal than in the HKEX proposal. We upgrade to Buy.

BE12:03pm

Redburn's positivity on Refinitiv suggests to me it's a Bloomberg office .....

12:03 pm
JP12:03pm

And here's UBS to finish:

JP12:03pm

HKEX has proposed a possible combination with LSE
HKEX has proposed a takeover offer for LSE that would value LSE at ~£83/share, with 24% of the offer in cash, at current HKEX prices. This offer implies a 23% premium to LSE's recent share price and a 47% premium on LSE's stand-alone share price prior to the announcement of the proposed Refinitv deal. The HKEx potential offer would be contingent on the termination of the proposed LSE-Refinitiv deal.

JP12:04pm

Creating a Global Exchange
HKEx's rationale for the proposed HKEx/LSE deal would be to create an exchange that offers a global footprint, "connecting the established financial markets in the West with the emerging financial markets in the East, particularly China." While HKEx speaks of "significant synergy potential", few details are provided. There are only few instances of cross-continental exchange mergers that have been completed successfully, as nationalistic concerns often arise.

12:03 pm
JP12:04pm

Does LSE entertain the offer?
While this development is very fresh, currently available information suggests that the offer, if accepted, would result in shareholders transferring their ownership from LSE shares into HKEX shares. Given the recent transformational announcement by LSE to acquire Refinitiv in early August, made by a CEO just 12-months into his role, we would be surprised to see LSE's management and board prefer a takeover bid from HKEx. Given the recent business disruptions in Hong Kong, we would argue that this adds to the potential perceived risk of a proposed LSE/HKEx merger.
Valuation: LSE rated Neutral; Standalone LSE Price Target of £55.50
We rate LSE Neutral.
